description: Catnip (Nepeta cataria) is a perennial herb known for its intoxicating effects on cats. Native to Europe and Asia, catnip is a member of the mint family and is valued for its aromatic foliage and attractive spikes of white or purple flowers. While catnip is best known for its appeal to cats, it also has culinary and medicinal uses for humans. Catnip is easy to grow in the garden or in containers and can be a valuable addition to any herb garden.
varieties: Catnip, also known as Nepeta cataria, is a member of the mint family and is known for its stimulating effect on cats. While there is only one species of catnip, different cultivars may vary slightly in flavor and potency. Common varieties include 'Nepeta cataria' and 'Nepeta x faassenii'. 'Nepeta cataria' is the most common variety and is widely used for its effects on cats.

sowingAndPlanting.sowingIndoorsDescription: Catnip seeds can be started indoors 6-8 weeks before the last frost date in your area. Plant seeds in biodegradable pots or trays filled with seed-starting mix. Sow seeds 1/4 inch deep and keep the soil consistently moist and warm (70-75°F). Provide ample light or use supplemental grow lights. Transplant seedlings outdoors once all danger of frost has passed and the soil has warmed up.
sowingAndPlanting.sowingOutdoorsDescription: Catnip seeds can also be directly seeded outdoors after the last frost date in your area. Choose a location with full sun to partial shade and well-drained soil. Plant seeds 1/4 inch deep and space them 18-24 inches apart. Keep the soil consistently moist until seedlings emerge.
sowingAndPlanting.season: Catnip should be planted after the last frost date in your area when the soil has warmed up. It prefers well-drained soil and can tolerate a wide range of pH levels.

careAndMaintenance.growingDescription: Catnip prefers full sun to partial shade and well-drained soil with a pH of 6.0-7.5. Water young plants regularly to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Once established, catnip is drought-tolerant and only requires occasional watering during dry periods.
careAndMaintenance.wateringNeeds: Regular watering when young, then occasional watering once established.
careAndMaintenance.soilFertility: Catnip is not heavy feeder and does not require fertilization. However, incorporating compost into the soil before planting can provide some nutrients.
careAndMaintenance.pruningRequirements: Prune catnip regularly to promote bushy growth and prevent it from becoming too leggy. Pinch off the tips of stems to encourage branching and remove spent flowers to prolong the blooming period.
careAndMaintenance.supportRequirements: Catnip does not typically require support.

harvestingAndStorage.timeToMaturity: Catnip typically matures and is ready for harvest 90-120 days after planting, depending on growing conditions.
harvestingAndStorage.storageRecommendations: Harvest catnip leaves and flowers as needed for fresh use or drying. Hang harvested stems upside down in a well-ventilated area out of direct sunlight to dry. Once dry, store the leaves and flowers in an airtight container in a cool, dark place.
harvestingAndStorage.harvestDescription: Harvest catnip leaves and flowers by cutting stems just above a set of leaves. Use fresh catnip immediately for your cat's enjoyment, or dry it for later use.

goodCompanionPlants.name: Cat Grass
goodCompanionPlants.description: Catnip and cat grass are complementary plants often grown together for the enjoyment of cats. Catnip provides stimulating effects for cats when ingested or rubbed against, while cat grass offers a safe and satisfying alternative to outdoor grass for cats to chew on.

goodCompanionPlants.name: Valerian
goodCompanionPlants.description: Valerian is a good companion for catnip as it attracts cats with its scent, similar to catnip. However, valerian has a calming effect on cats, which can complement the stimulating effects of catnip, providing a range of experiences for feline enrichment.

goodCompanionPlants.name: Lavender
goodCompanionPlants.description: Lavender can be a beneficial companion for catnip as it attracts pollinators like bees and butterflies while repelling pests like mosquitoes and flies. Additionally, the calming aroma of lavender may help create a relaxing environment for both humans and cats.

badCompanionPlants.name: Toxic Plants
badCompanionPlants.description: Avoid planting catnip near toxic plants that could harm cats if ingested. Make sure to research any potential toxic plants in your garden and keep them separated from catnip to ensure the safety of your pets.

tipsAndTricks: Choose a planting site with well-drained soil and full sun exposure.
Directly sow catnip seeds outdoors in the spring after the last frost, or start seeds indoors 6-8 weeks before the last frost date.
Water catnip regularly, providing about 1 inch of water per week, and mulch to conserve moisture and suppress weeds.
Fertilize catnip with a balanced fertilizer or compost tea every 4-6 weeks during the growing season, following package instructions.
Harvest catnip leaves and flowers as needed for drying or fresh use by snipping them from the stem.
Monitor plants regularly for signs of pests such as aphids and spider mites. Use insecticidal soap or neem oil as needed.
Watch for symptoms of diseases like powdery mildew and leaf spot. Provide good air circulation and avoid overhead watering to reduce humidity around plants.
Allow some catnip flowers to go to seed to ensure a continuous supply of plants in subsequent seasons.
Protect catnip plants from excessive browsing by cats, especially during the flowering stage when they are most attractive to felines.
